text: cookie week is continuing today of
making a citrus thumbprint start off by
zesting your citrus I have one lemon and
one lime you need a tablespoon each of
zest and juice from each of them it's
very citrusy hence the name
I love citrus I think it's such a bright
fresh flavor at the holidays tablespoon
of this juice so I'm actually gonna
measure it cuz I don't want to overdo it
I know you're thinking what you measure
never yet it does happen and then the
same thing with lime I have a special
treat coming up we're gonna have a guest
who's gonna do something really special
with our cookies I bet you guys are
gonna love it so you're gonna have to
stay tuned and see what I'm talking
about watch every video and then you'll
find out all right so that's your citrus
for the dry ingredients I have two and a
half cups of all-purpose flour this was
sifted and then measured so I already
have it in my bowl and a half a teaspoon
of fine salt as well as a half a cup of
confectioner's sugar can whisk those
ingredients together in my mixer I have
two sticks of unsalted butter room
temperature as well as a quarter cup of
granulated sugar quite warm in here so
my butter is already getting creamy to
the butter mixture you can add your
citrus juices and zest
scrape your ball this is basically like
a shortbread cookie I've been making a
lot of short breads because they're so
simple and adaptable this one gets
rolled into balls and baked instead of
pressed into a pan and baked now you can
add your dry ingredients I like to take
my butter out of the refrigerator a few
hours ahead of time so that it's truly
room temperature makes it so much easier
just go ahead and add all of it and then
you want to be careful here with the
flour as I always say don't turn it on
too high
unless you want to get showered in flour
beat til that combines everything should
come together really well this is a
pretty buttery dough so it shouldn't be
a struggle at all get off now these
citrus thumb prints are a little bit
delicate for packing but if you have
some nice little boxes and you can put
them in one layer they're so special and
beautiful they're like little jewels
give it another stir to fully combine
and then you can scoop it have your oven
preheating to 325 degrees I have an ice
cream scoop if you have one that's about
a tablespoon you can use that for this
otherwise you can approximate they don't
need to be exactly a tablespoon roll
them into balls and then get them onto
parchment lined baking sheets you're
gonna want to get these into a freezer
for about 10 minutes just so they firm
up a little bit so they hold their shape
nicely when you put them into the oven
325 degree oven when your cookies have
baked for 10 minutes it's time to make
the thumbprint so use the bottom of a
melon baller or a measuring spoon to
make an indent in the cookies this is
going to hold the jam putting the dent
in now makes it so that they'll stay a
little better if you put them in in the
beginning you generally have to take
them out and reform them anyway so I
like to do it halfway through the
cooking now you want to get the cookies
back into the oven until they're set and
just light golden brown around the edges
be about 12 more minutes
when they come out of the oven you want
to transfer them to a wire rack and let
them cool for about 10 minutes but while
they're still slightly warm you want to
toss them in confectioner sugar just
toss your cookies toss your cookies
that's funny
if you're making these a head so you
want to make them as a gift or something
you can bake them ahead and then freeze
them and then take them out warm them
just slightly and toss them in the
confectioner sugar you don't want to do
this too far ahead because it does
absorb as they sit now for extra special
coating this
sift more confectioner sugar over the
top use a small sieve for this and now
you can fill with your jam I'm using
apricot jam you can use a marmalade you
can use lemon curd it's such a beautiful
presentation I think it's about a half a
teaspoon of jam that goes into each one
and now if you want these to set a
little bit which is really nice
particularly if you're packing them is
you can put this back into the oven for
about five minutes and the jam will just
melt a tiny bit and then when it cools
down it'll set and it'll be tacky on top
instead of loose like this but if you're
serving them right away and you're not
packing them up you can just go ahead
and enjoy them right away mmm oh
